question: How do the effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance vary across different ocean basins?
answer: Across multiple ocean basins, studies report varied effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance. In the Mediterranean Sea, site comparisons reported no increase in biomass for some targeted species 2–13 years after closure compared to a fished area, while other studies in this and additional basins recorded higher abundances for subsets of species (e.g., some commercially targeted and non-targeted groups) [2667]. In the Indian Ocean and Gulf of Mexico, among site comparison studies, some found higher abundances for parts of the fish community, while others reported mixed outcomes across species/groups [2667]. In the South Atlantic Ocean, one study found no change in fish species composition relative to fished areas, and among abundance-focused comparisons spanning this and other basins, responses ranged from higher abundances in some commercially exploited species to mixed effects depending on exploitation history [2667]. In the Tasman Sea, a before-and-after study found lower abundances for most species two years after closure in an estuary, while another study in a reserve zone closed to commercial trapping reported abundance patterns that varied over a decade and among fish groups [2667]. In the South China Sea, overall fish density in the wider region increased within five years after reserves limiting commercial fishing were created, alongside shifts in assemblage composition [2667].
